```python

```

comments.body:
Most of these examples use quoted strings where it is not required.
We tend to only quote strings that requires quoting (i.e. integers as string, colon-space combo, date formats, etc...)
If we expect people to pick up how YAML works it helps to only quote when it is required.
@dagwieers by convention we quote all of the F5 example strings exactly because users do not know "where it is required"

Well, then they will never really know and think they always have to quote. I don't think it's better to teach them to always quote, and certainly not using double quotes.

Besides, you're not being consistent, you're not quoting the task name value and delegate_to.
I'm being consistent across the list of parameters to the module; not the task level params ;-)

And what does that teach our users ? ;-)

That's why I prefer consistency across the board with a very simple rule for contributors. Only quote when it is necessary (and preferably use single quotes if you have to).

You can find some information to why in the Windows documentation (soon to be released): https://github.com/ansible/community/wiki/Windows%3A-documentation#yaml-syntax-preferred

I understand that not in all cases you have these complexities, but it becomes worse if we have to teach users different rules depending on the platform used, or the technology domain.

Hi
Use of quotes isn't a debate for this PR, though is something that may be worth a proposal.
As we don't have this documented (`dev_guide`) there are no official rules, so this module is correct, and consistent.
